_header: Go little quire and swift thy princess dress
Note:
Ringler Jr. (1992)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler , TM 475.
Title(s): On the Nightingale as a symbol of Christ
Subjects: nightingale; dream poems; Christ, symbols of
_description: John Lydgate, On the Nightingale as a symbol of Christ — fifty-nine rhyme royal stanzas including a dedication of six stanzas

BodLatMisC66.First Lines:
…Meved of corage by vertew of the seasonIn pryme tens
                    renobled yere by yere…
BodLatMisC66.Last Lines:
…How that this brid amang hir notes gladRight of her deth a
                    nowte of mornyng made
BodLatMisC66.Note:
Lacks lines 1-21; lines 50-56 follow line 112; lines 396-7
                    reversed.

OxfCCC203.First Lines:
Go lityll quayere And swyft thy prynses dresse[ ]
                    humble [ ]…
OxfCCC203.Last Lines:
…That fro this worlde when so we schall deseuerIn yoye
                    eternall with hym there to perseuere
OxfCCC203.Editions:
Glauning,  Otto,
                        ed.  
             Lydgate’s Two Nightingale Poems.
EETS
         e.s. 80 (1900); repr. 1987: 2-15 (st. 1 & 2 only).
Adams,  Robert, Hoyt N. Duggan,  Eric Eliason,  Ralph Hanna,  John Price-Wilkin,   and  Thorlac Turville-Petre, eds.  
             The Piers Plowman Electronic Archive, Vol. 1: Oxford, Corpus Christi College, MS 201 (F).
            
         SEENET Series A.1  William Langland (2014).

BlCottCalAII.First Lines:
…Commandyng theym to here wyth tendernesseOf this your
                    nightyngale the gostly sense…
BlCottCalAII.Last Lines:
…That fro this worlde when so we shall deseuerIn Ioye eternall
                    with hym ther to perseuer
BlCottCalAII.Note:
Stanzas 1-2 wanting, probably due to lost leaf or leaves; ‘Amen /
                    Explicit’ by scribe after last line.
BlCottCalAII.Attributed Title:
The nyghtyngale (added by sixteenth-century hand, upper margin, f. 59); The
                    nyghtynghale (by scribe as RT on verso leaves); Another poeme intitled the
                    nightingall (f. 1, sixteenth-century list of contents)
BlCottCalAII.Editions:
Glauning,  Otto,
                        ed.  
             Lydgate’s Two Nightingale Poems.
EETS
         e.s. 80 (1900); repr. 1987: 2-15 (st. 1 & 2 from Oxford,  Corpus Christi College 203).
